Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Lens-Free Imaging: Can Signal Processing Replace Lenses?

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The basic design of the camera has remained unchanged for centuries. To acquire an image, light from the scene is focused using a lens onto an image sensor. This design has served users well in a broad range of applications, with lenses forming the bedrock of current imaging practice. Unfortunately, lenses also introduce a number of limitations. First, while image sensors are typically thin, cameras end up being thick due to the lens complexity and the large distance between the lens and sensor required to achieve focus. Second, while Moore?s Law has cut the cost of image sensors exponentially over time, lenses, and thus cameras, do not benefit from this exponential scaling, particularly at wavelengths further into the infrared and ultraviolet, where inexpensive glass and plastics cannot be used. Third, lens-based cameras invariably require post-fabrication assembly, resulting in manufacturing inefficiencies.

In this project, the PIs develop new camera architectures that dispense with lenses completely. Lens-free cameras retain the high light-throughput of lens-based cameras, have a thin form factor, and are amenable to direct fabrication while operating over a wide spectral range. The design replaces the lens with a series of coded masks placed almost immediately atop a bare conventional sensor and uses a computational algorithm to recover the image from the sensor measurements. The goal of this project is a modern signal processing based framework for the design, optimization and development of lens free and refractive optics-free imaging systems that will establish the fundamental limits of imaging with such systems. This will revolutionize imaging capabilities and, for the first time, enable thin, cameras that can directly be fabricated using traditional semiconductor fabrication tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The last few decades have seen an explosion in the use of cameras and other imaging devices. Due to advances in image processing and computer vision, cameras are now being used in a wide variety of applications. It is now common to find camera modules in houses for baby monitoring, in microscopes for biological imaging, and in devices for biometric authentication. However, these images are almost always captured with standard lens-based systems. While image sensors are typically thin and inexpensive, lenses add thickness and cost to camera systems, hindering their use in applications with strict cost and size constraints. To overcome this, we design Lens-Free Camera (LFC) systems, each consisting of an image sensor and a thin light modulating mask installed a few hundred microns above the sensor. Such a system yields a very thin imaging system and one that can potentially be mass produced at very low cost. In this project, we focused on (1) designing the modulation mask to produce high-resolution images, (2) designing masks and algorithms for specific vision tasks, (3) performing face detection and verification with an LFC, and (4) building a thin lens-free microscope.

We designed two types of modulation masks: an amplitude modulation mask and a phase modulation mask. For both, the mask performs a linear mapping on the scene, and the output is then measured by the image sensor. In our work, we studied how to design the mask to provide linear mappings favorable for both high resolution reconstructions and for specific vision tasks. As an example, we designed phase masks for edge extraction such that the sensor directly measures the edges of the scene.

With regards to the incorporation of LFCs for vision tasks, we studied the performance of our lens-free design for the tasks of face detection and verification. We demonstrate reasonable accuracy for these tasks by using deep learning techniques on the reconstructed lens-free images. Further, we built a lens-free face image dataset containing more than 24,000 images that will be released to the public to more easily facilitate additional research for lens-free cameras.

For microscopy, we fabricated a thin lens-free device that can perform single-shot 3D imaging in the microscopic scale. This was done by designing an efficient depth-dependent calibration and reconstruction scheme in order to reconstruct the scene at multiple depth planes from a single capture. We demonstrated high-resolution image and video captures of the Hydra microorganism.

Broader Impact: The wide-reaching impact of this project has implications in scientific/medical imaging, surveillance, and consumer imaging. By allowing imaging in a very thin package, lens-free cameras can be used for biological imaging in very narrow areas or to incorporate imaging capabilities to very thin objects. The performance of computer vision tasks with lens-free cameras can find applications in Internet of Things, biometric authentication, and others. Multiple undergraduate students have also been trained in research by contributing to this project.
